page.lettertext:
fol.202r
Belgia 1590: July
1590 14 July [.] my L. Trea
s
May it please yo
r
L. I was visited of late by
Mons
r
Buis
, whose affection devoted to her
Ma
ties
service, yo
r
L. hath knowen by my former letters,
as also otherwise by his actions heretofore. Of the
conference that was between us, I have thought
very requisit, to impart some pointes of moment
to yo
r
L. to be further considered, as in yo
r
judge-
ment and wisdome, yo
w
shall thinke expedient.
Uppon occasion of talke astouching
Justinus
, and
S
t
Aldegonde
, he was fully persuaded, that whatsoever
nowe
is pretended by them, had
Paris
bin wonne,
and suche further prosperitie befallen
e
King
, as
they did hastely
imagine
look for
, they were fully determi-
ned to have moved
e King, to accept of these
Provinces. And wheras
Count Maurice
giveth out,
that Justinus errant to
e K. was only to solicite for
some part of
e Countes patrimonie in
Burgundie
,
whiche (as he saieth), was lately recovered from
e Enemie by
e King, he avocheth flatly, that it
is but a mere excuse, for that
e count hath no-
thing to claime in ether Burgundie. His fathers
interest was in
e Count of Burgundie, whiche is
e Kinges of
Spaine
, wherof
e French K. doth
nether challenge, nor enjoy any part: and in
e
Duchie of Burgundie, w
ch
apperteneth to
Fraunce
, he
never had any thing. There are only certaine
actions of
e mortuarie house of his father, whiche
belong to
e
Countesse of Beuren
his sister, and no-
thing at all to himself. Howbeit Count Maurice, he
thinkes, is muche seduced by some naughtie instru-
ments about him. But if her Ma
tie
could winne
him, and would be induced theruppon to make
fol.202v
Belgia: 1590: July
him her lieutenant in these contreis, he made no [dout]
but
e Count would accept it for a singular
favo
r
and
hono
r
and it would also prove
e readiest and
e safest
course, aswel for her Ma
tie
as
e contrey. His opi-
nion is further, that her Hig
nes
should use no longe
delay in
e mater, for that he standeth assured, ther
is some secret practise a foote in
e Frenche kinges
behalf. For he cometh into divers places
[an]
d com-
panies, and talketh w
t
persons of divers q
a
lities and
callinges, and of sundrie Provinces, whose usual
communication is in commendac
o
n of
e Frenche,
and in disgrace of
e English nation, as by whome
they say, they have receaved more hurt then benefit
whiche they
would
verifie continually by my
L.
of Leicesters
proceedinges: alleaging w
t
all that
her Ma
tie
in shewe hath refused
e Soveraigntie of
these contreis, yet she hath sought underhand, both
by him, and by other of her ministers, to possesse their
townes, and so to deprive them of their liberties,
and to bring them into servitude. This he af-
firmeth, is
e common speeche among a great
many, ether suborned unto it, or untruly infor-
med, by suche as would bring in
e Frenche. And
above all other places, he thought it needfull for
her Ma
tie
to keepe good watche in
Zeland
.
To prevent
e inconvenience that might growe to
her Ma
tie
by these factious devises, he held it very
necessarie, that certaine letters should be adres-
sed from her Hignes not only to this college heere
of
e
General states
, but to
e several Provinces,
and to
e principal townes of every Province, the
effect of w
ch
letters should be this, or the like,
fol.203r
Belgia: 1590: July
That forasmuche as her Ma
tie
had at sundrie ti-
mes of late, and in sundrie affaires importing
e
good of these contreis, written very earnestly to their
Deputies in
e Assembly of
e General states at the
Hage
, and had ether
receaved
no answear from them, or
was foded forthe in vaine w
t
promises and no per-
fourmance; and had also understood, that some of
e
forsaid affaires, had bin concealed by them in their
assembly, and not further imparted to their superio
rs
,
e particular Provinces, she was therfore forced
at this present to deale more directly and parti-
cularly w
t
them, and to lett them understand
that she doth repute her self to be highly wronged, and
touched in Hono
r
, by
e sinister practises, and untrue
reportes of some seditious persons, w
ch
of a perverse
disposition, and for
e better effecting of their
privat desseignes, endevo
r
continually to persuade
the inhabitants of these contreis, that her Ma
ties
assi-
stance unto them hath bin nothing, that it hath bin
more domageable then beneficiall, and that her
Ma
tie
doth reject
e soveraigntie in wordes, but
hath ever sought by her deedes, and by
e actions of
her ministers, to bring their townes in subjection:
w
t
other like untrue, and injurious imputations.
To w
ch
cause she doth lett them understand,
hath bin moved to doe them to witte
that
In w
ch
respect she is
desirous to declare
unto th
e
, that the
manifold and weightie
affaires
causes wher-
w
t
she is daily c
o
-
bred and every day
more
in her Roial estate
will not affourd
her
e
c
o
venient
meanes to acquit
of all
e
ticular
-
ceedinges of her sub-
jectes,
but
in these
c
o
treis but
whatsoever hath bin done heretofore, or shall be hereafter,
by any of her subjects,
them ministers heere in these contreis
if it have tended to other,
then
e publicke good of their state, she doth utterly
disavowe it, for that her intention was never other,
nor is not at this present, but to maintene their li-
berties to
e uttermost, and to leave their townes to
be enjoied by themselves, as thinges that she
utterly
greatly
disliketh to be presented unto her, having only had
fol.203v
Belgia: 1590: July
a purpose to protect them from
e tyrannie of
e
Enemie, whiche she is assured she hath done
to her excessive charges
and
doth at this present
to
e daunger of her owne estate
to
e viewe of all
e worlde,
and
will
doth minde
continewe
it
so
as long, as she may
perceave
finde
on
their part a th
a
kful acknowledgement. And
therupon she doth
request
require
them, not to yeld so muche,
not
to
e weaknes of some mens conceats, that thinke
e contrary, or to
e malice of others, that for some
particular respect, spredde suche false reportes:
w
t
suche
addition of suche further mater,
in respect
of her excessive charges, and of
e daunger wherto her owne realme is brought &c
. as shall be
thought convenient. This is
e summe of
a longer discourse between M
r
Buis and me:
wherew
t
I acquainted
M
r
Wilkes
at large
, who hath bin
sins at
Leiden
w
t
him, and hath had
e like con-
ference, as I thinke he himself will certifie yo
r
L.
For mine owne
part
opini
o
I doe thinke M
r
Buis informac
o
n to be very true, and his councel
uppon it to be sound, and sincere, and voide of
all daunger. Nevertheles before there be any
thing resolved, I could wishe to see their answears
to o
r
first and second propositions, and accordingly
as they shewe them selves inclined, so to deale as
Mons
r
Buis doth advise, or otherwise: albeit for
mine owne part, I have made a long triall of
their humors, and
for
in
their cariage towardes her
Ma
tie
I have seene litle chaunge, but for the worse.
And so referring these maters to yo
r
L. considera-
tion I take my humble leave. From
e Hage.
Julij 14. 90.
Yo
r
L. most humbly bounden
Tho. Bodley
Before
e sending hereof we receaved
certaine Apostils for
e Gen eral states
up
o
o
r
first
positions, w
ch
M
r
Wilkes
will send to yo
r
L. It is nowe a
just
moneth
that
we
have
bin
delaied
us
and for mine owne
t although I expected fr
o
them but a
slender satisfaction, yet nowe I finde
it
[.]
i
ferior to that expectation.
